title: Determining the Composition of an Object

previous.title: Classifying Newly Detected Solar System Objects

content: To determine the surface composition, astronomers look at the differences in brightness of an asteroid from one filter to the next. The two plots below show C-class and S-class asteroids when measured through Rubin Observatory’s g, r, i, and z filters. For each plot, the horizontal (x) axis shows four filters. The vertical (y) axis is a measure of brightness compared to the g filter. For example, if the r filter shows a brightness value of 3, it means that the asteroid appeared three times brighter through the r filter than it was when measured through the g filter. In summary, don’t pay attention to the height of the plot, rather it’s the shape of the plot. For C-Class asteroids the plot is relatively flat across the r, i, z filter range. For S-Class asteroids the plot increases from r to i filters but then decreases from i to z filters.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: At least one of your three objects newly detected by Rubin Observatory is an NEO. Determine its type (C or S) by examining a plot of its brightness measurements through different filters. Explain how you decided.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Enter the absolute magnitude and albedo of your NEO to determine its diameter. The average albedo for C-class asteroids is 0.06 and the average albedo for S-class asteroids is 0.20.
